newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: KEDO delegation to visit N.Korea next month - paper.
newsitem.headline: KEDO delegation to visit N.Korea next month - paper.

text.p: An international consortium helping set up North Korea's nuclear energy programme plans to send a survey team early in February to Shinpo where light-water reactors are to be built, domestic media reported on Sunday.
"We will be able to dispatch the seventh site survey team to North Korea early next month," The Chosun Ilbo quoted a consortium official as saying.

The U.S.-led consortium, called the Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organisation (KEDO), would also send a working level consultation team to discuss issues of logistics and other details with Pyongyang.
On Friday, Seoul officials said a landmark nuclear agreement with North Korea would be back on track next week when KEDO sign protocols with North Korea for building light-water reactors.
The move was the first concrete step to repair damage from the incursion of a North Korean submarine into the South in September. It followed an apology by Pyongyang over the incident last Sunday.
The incursion froze all contacts between the two Koreas.
The KEDO official was quoted as saying a survey team of about 60 people would stay for five months.
North Korea and the United States signed the landmark agreement in Geneva in October 1994 to end the crisis over the North's suspected nuclear weapons development.

KEDO is a consortium created by South Korea, the United States and Japan to implement the Geneva accord under which Pyongyang promised to dismantle its weapons-grade nuclear programme in return for safer light-water reactors.
Under the $4.5 billion deal, Pyongyang will be provided with two light-water reactors and interim supplies of fuel oil.
